review.title: Modeling Variations of First-Order Horn Abduction in Answer Set Programming
review.abstract: We study abduction in First Order Horn logic theories where all atoms can be abduced and we are looking for prefered solutions with respect to objective functions cardinality minimality, Coherence, or Weighted Abduction. We represent this reasoning problem in Answer Set Programming (ASP), in order to obtain a flexible framework for experimenting with global constraints and objective functions, and to test the boundaries of what is possible with ASP, because realizing this problem in ASP is challenging as it requires value invention and equivalence between certain constants as the Unique Names Assumption does not hold in general. For permitting reasoning in cyclic theories, we formally describe fine-grained variations of limiting Skolemization. We evaluate our encodings and extensions experimentally on the ACCEL benchmark for plan recognition in Natural Language Understanding. Our encodings are publicly available, modular, and our approach is more efficient than state-of-the-art solvers on the ACCEL benchmark. We identify term equivalence as a main instantiation bottleneck, and experiment with on-demand constraints that were used to eliminate the same bottleneck in state-of-the-art solvers and make them applicable for larger datasets. Surprisingly, experiments show that this method is beneficial only for cardinality minimality with our ASP encodings.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: We give a brief introduction to abduction in general and the variations of horn abduction of the First Order as used in processing natural language, describe the Accel benchmark, which contains examples of such thinking problems, and give an introduction to ASP and HEX. In the following we write variables in logical expressions and ASP rules, starting with uppercase letters and constants, starting with lowercase letters.

sections.heading: 2.1 Abduction and Preferences on Abductive Explanations
sections.text: Abduction, originally described in [Pei55], can logically be defined as follows: Given a set B of background knowledge and an observation O, we find a set H of hypotheses atoms such that observation O (also referred to as "goal") is an existentially quantified conjunction of atoms V1,., Vk: o1 (V1,.,.) sections.heading: 2.3 Answer Set Programming
sections.text: Assuming familiarity with ASP [GL88, Lif08, EIK09, GKS12], we will output only brief preliminary data from HEX programs [EFI + 16] that extend the ASP Core 2 standard [CFG + 12]. We will use programs with (uninterpreted) function symbols, aggregates, decisions, and weak constraints. Constant names serve as constant terms and names for uninterpreted functions. The set of terms T is recursively defined, and external predicate names, which we will name with the first letter in uppercase, beginning with "&," respectively. Constant names serve as constant names, and names for uninterpreted terms. It is the smallest group that contains N, X as uninterpreted function terms f (t1,., tn), where f.

sections.heading: 3 ASP Encodings
sections.text: All encodings consist of a deterministic part that contains all the atoms that can potentially be used to form a hypothesis, i.e., to justify the goal. Some encodings also explicitly represent conclusions that lead to these atoms. All encodings guess an equivalence relationship across all the terms in these "potentially interesting" atoms to deal with term equivalence. In Bwd encodings, the detection graph actually used is non-deterministically guessed, while the Fwd-A encoding makes a guess about derived atoms and verifies whether the goals are true in the face of these atoms. Variations of Bwd encodings result in factoring in different ways. Next, we give common aspects of all encodings, then give each encoding in detail c, and finally a summary of the differences between the encodings.

sections.heading: 3.6 Summary
sections.text: Table 1 gives an overview of our encodings. Encodings in the Bwd family represent deterministically the maximum potential proof graph and all its conclusions, while Fwd-A represents only atoms in the hypothesis. The justification of atoms in the proof curve is non-deterministically guessed as one of three classes by Bwd-Gand one of two classes by Bwd-AI and Bwd-A in the Bwd coding of targets to abductors (backwards) and of hijacked atoms to targets (forwards) in Fwd-A. The justification of targets and atoms in the hypothesis is non-deterministically guessed as one of three classes by Bwd-Gand one of two classes by Bwd-AI and Bwd-A.

sections.heading: 4 Extensions
sections.text: The ASP encodings specified so far are realized in pure ASP Core 2 syntax and do not require additional features specific to specific solver tools. However, these encodings have two disadvantages: they can only represent acyclic theories, and they have performance problems related to the size of the instantiation of the transitivity constraint for equivalents. Next, we formalize two extensions of these encodings and describe their computational implementation. In Section 4.1, we introduce Flexible Value Invention for fine-grained control of scolemization, which makes our encodings applicable to cyclic theories. In Section 4.2, we show how we can replace certain constraints in our encodings with rotten variants to reduce the grounding size and potentially improve evaluation performance. Both extensions are formally described in HEX formalism. Section 4.3 describes how we have implemented these extensions using the Python library of Clingo.

sections.heading: 4.2 On-Demand Constraints
sections.text: In the set of rules common to all encodings (section 3.1), we present the transitivity of the equivalence ratio eq as a constraint (30), rather than the more commonly used rule eq (A, C) eq (A, B), eq (B, C), A 6 = B, B 6 = C, A 6 = C. The formulation as a constraint allows us to eliminate (30) from the encoding and inertia only create those instances of (30) that are violated in the search for the optimal solution. Such a lazy instantiation is easy for constraints, but not for rules in current solvers, since the addition of a new rule changes the representation of the solver (usually the Clark completion) of all rules with the same head in the program. Formally, we place lazy constraints in HEX (cf.

sections.heading: 4.3 Implementation
sections.text: We formulated the question of the value of invention and on-demand constraints using HEX as a formal framework. In preliminary experiments, we identified a performance problem in the dlvhex solver that was not easy to fix, so we decided to implement the extensions with the Gringo and Clasp Python libraries [GKS14], which presented additional challenges that we discuss next.Flexible skolemization can be realized by replacing external atoms of the Form & Skolem [a, i, Y1, Ym] (Zi) with the expression Zi = @ skolemization.

metadata.abstractText: We study abduction in First Order Horn logic theories where all atoms can be abduced and we are looking for preferred solutions with respect to three objective functions: cardinality minimality, coherence, and weighted abduction. We represent this reasoning problem in Answer Set Programming (ASP), in order to obtain a flexible framework for experimenting with global constraints and objective functions, and to test the boundaries of what is possible with ASP. Realizing this problem in ASP is challenging as it requires value invention and equivalence between certain constants, because the Unique Names Assumption does not hold in general. To permit reasoning in cyclic theories, we formally describe fine-grained variations of limiting Skolemization. We identify term equivalence as a main instantiation bottleneck, and improve the efficiency of our approach with on-demand constraints that were used to eliminate the same bottleneck in state-of-the-art solvers. We evaluate our approach experimentally on the ACCEL benchmark for plan recognition in Natural Language Understanding. Our encodings are publicly available, modular, and our approach is more efficient than state-of-the-art solvers on the ACCEL benchmark.
